awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: IA: Collaborative Research: From Bytes to Watts - A Data Science Solution to Improve Wind Energy Reliability and Operation
awd_abstract_narration:
The collective efforts in aerospace, civil, electrical, and mechanical engineering areas have led to remarkable progresses in wind energy. Larger turbines are designed and installed, and wind farms are nowadays built at locations where wind is even more intermittent and maintenance equipment is less accessible. This adds new challenges to ensuring operational reliability. To cope with these challenges, along with the rapid advancement in microelectronics, modern wind farms are equipped with a large number and variety of sensors, including, at the turbine level, anemometers, tachometers, accelerometers, thermometers, strain sensors, and power meters, and at the farm level, anemometers, vanes, sonars, thermometers, humidity meters, pressure meters, among others. It is worth noting that all these data are currently analyzed/utilized only in their respective domains. The big data challenges in this project include how to best use spatio-temporal data for wind forecast, how to use data of different nature (wind, power, load etc.) and data of different sources (physical data versus computer simulation data) for power production assessment in a computationally efficient manner, and finally how to integrate these three sets of solutions into a reliable and efficient computational platform. The proposed research and education activities will make a paradigm shift in the wind industry by demonstrating how dramatically data science innovations can benefit the industry. The PIs will disseminate the research findings through classroom teaching, journal/conference publications, industry workshops, and data/software sharing. The summer internship opportunities and undergraduate research help train the next generation workforce to be better versed with data science methodologies.

The critical barrier to cost effective wind power and its general adoption is partly rooted in wind stochasticity, severely complicating wind power production optimization and cost reduction. The long-term viability of wind energy hinges upon a good understanding of its production reliability, which is affected in turn by the predictability of wind and power productivity of wind turbines. Furthermore, the productivity of a wind turbine comprises two aspects: its ability of converting wind into power during its operation and the availability of wind turbines. Three inter-related research efforts will enhance wind energy reliability and productivity): (1) spatio-temporal analysis (for wind forecast) (2) conditional density estimation (for wind-to-power conversion assessment); and (3) importance sampling (for turbine reliability assessment and improvement). Significant data resourced provided by industry partners in the research, coupled with models and computational resources, will enable better prediction of wind profiles and utilization.  In addition, the team will develop dedicated reconfigurable field programmable gate array (FPGA) processors that will be 50 to 500 times faster than general-purpose CPUs for both on-site and central control processing and have small form-factor, low cost and energy efficient to enable agile development under severe outdoor conditions at wind farms.

por.por_cntn:
Wind energy is one of the fastest-growing clean energy sources and plays a significant role in reducing global carbon emission and combatting climate change. But the benefit of wind energy is not fully taken advantage of. In order to help the global community achieve carbon net zero, the global wind power growth needs to be doubled now, or to be tripled after 2030 if on the current trajectory. The critical barrier is rooted in wind stochasticity, severely complicating wind power production optimization and cost reduction.  There exists already a large amount of data accumulated during the design, testing, and operations of wind turbines. There are, however, major technical challenges in analyzing these data owing to data complexity, heterogeneity, and computational scalability. Envisioning a great opportunity for incorporating big data analytics to fundamentally improve the predictability of wind and the power productivity of wind turbines, we form a university-industry-government collaborative research team, with Texas A&M University (TAMU) as the lead, together with the University of Connecticut, University of Michigan, University of California at Santa Barbara, National Renewable Energy Lab, and multiple industrial partners, for developing data science methods to address practical needs in wind energy applications. This report summarizes TAMU's research outcomes, as follows:

(a)  TAMU team analyzed the nonstationary and asymmetric characteristics of spatio-temporal wind data, motivating the development of a special class of wind forecasting method, known as regime-switching. While nonstationary covariance structures do exist, using them is not easy.  Past research found that a simpler approach is to compartmentalize the nonstationary variables into a finite number of disjoint intervals, each of which is referred to as a regime.  Within a regime, the underlying wind process is assumed stationary. To account for the overall non-stationarity, a mechanism is needed for the forecasting model to transition from one regime to another, as the underlying wind process is progressing. The team's regime switching-based forecasting method uses a combination of three wind speed regimes and two wind direction regimes, producing a total of six regimes.  The resulting method outperformed a large number of alternatives available in the literature in terms of forecasting accuracy for up to 12 hours ahead.

 (b)  TAMU team developed a suite of methods for wind turbine performance analysis. In this undertaking, the team infused the engineering knowledge to the data science models, such as devising a physics-informed nonparametric functional regression model answering the question of which inputs should be used. To answer the question of which data subsets to be used for training, the team introduced causal inference methodologies--popular in social science but less known in engineering--into wind engineering. The team's final piece that builds the complete pipeline from data to decision is a method for comparing nonparametric functional curves and quantifying the uncertainty in such comparison.

 (c)  UCSB subteam had primarily worked on development of a series of algorithmic/hardware/architectural techniques for accelerating key computational kernels on dedicated low-power hardware computing platforms.  First, we developed a low-power field programmable gate array (FPGA) based hardware acceleration solution for SVD, a computationally expensive kernel needed in the spatial and temporal pattern decomposition task of the project, achieving 80X to 300X speedups over SVD solvers running on high-performance CPUs.  Furthermore, we developed an FPGA architecture and realization for accelerating the No-U-Turn sampler, which is a state-of-the-art Hamiltonian Monte Carlo sampling technique and can be leveraged for statistical learning and reliability analysis. Finally, we investigated how to use normalizing flows as a powerful tool for modeling complex probabilistic distributions such as ones with multi-modal characteristics. We studied a family of the state-of-the-art normalizing flows while focusing on performance/computational cost tradeoff and joint optimization. We investigated suitable hardware architectures of normalizing flows on low-power digital platforms such as FPGAs.

The lead PI Dr. Ding published a research monograph, Data Science for Wind Energy, in 2019.  Our team also developed a DSWE software package, available in both R and Python, which implemented 17 functions resulting from this research. Students who worked on the project received training in both data science and wind energy, covering AI/machine learning, renewable energy systems and sustainability, and fast computation on low-power hardware. The research team presented their methods and ideas not only to their own professional affiliations but also to groups across disciplinary boundaries and to their industrial partners. Two Ph.D. graduate joined academia as assistant professors and one joined industry as a data scientist. All students received several awards and recognitions for their work supported by this project. The paper on accelerating the No-U-Turn sampler received the sole Best Paper Award from the International Conference on Application-specific Systems, Architectures and Processors in 2021. The PI Dr. Ding received the Institute of Industrial and Systems Engineers (IISE)'s 2019 Technical Innovation Award and the team was awarded the Institute for Operations Research and the Management Sciences (INFORMS)'s 2022 Impact Prize.
